summary: This is an email from Assistant U.S. Attorney Maurene Comey to FBI agents regarding Ghislaine Maxwell's request to review discovery photos on a secure laptop alone at the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC). The email seeks the FBI's position on whether Maxwell can review the materials without an attorney present, noting the need to explain any denial to Judge Nathan.

persons.name: Maurene Comey
persons.context: Author of the email, coordinating with FBI agents regarding Ghislaine Maxwell's discovery review arrangements at MDC.

persons.name: Amanda N. Young
persons.context: FBI agent copied on the email regarding Maxwell's discovery review request.

persons.name: Paul Byrne
persons.context: Primary FBI recipient of the email regarding Maxwell's discovery review request.

persons.name: Lam Pomerantz
persons.context: Assistant U.S. Attorney copied on the email regarding Maxwell's discovery review.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The accused requesting to review discovery photos on a secure laptop alone at MDC without her attorneys present.

persons.name: Judge Nathan
persons.context: Presiding judge mentioned; the prosecution needs to be prepared to explain to her why Maxwell cannot review discovery alone if the FBI denies the request.

connections.description: Comey is coordinating with FBI agent Young regarding discovery procedures for Ghislaine Maxwell's case.
Comey is directly communicating with FBI agent Byrne to get the FBI's position on Maxwell's discovery review request.
Both are Assistant U.S. Attorneys working on the Maxwell case, with Pomerantz copied on the correspondence.
Judge Nathan is the presiding judge in Maxwell's case; the prosecution must justify decisions to her court.

events.title: Maxwell's Scheduled Discovery Review
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's attorneys arranged for her to review discovery photos on a secure laptop at the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC) from 8am to 3pm.

keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell's attorneys requested she be allowed to review discovery photos on a secure laptop alone at MDC because no attorney was available to be present.
The prosecution (AUSA Maurene Comey) sought the FBI's position on whether Maxwell could review materials without attorney supervision, citing security concerns in a jail setting.
The email indicates the prosecution needed to be prepared to justify any denial of Maxwell's request to Judge Nathan, showing judicial oversight of discovery procedures.
The correspondence reveals logistical coordination between the U.S. Attorney's Office and FBI regarding defendant access to discovery materials in a high-profile case.
